p: As of March 31, 2020, the CDC reported that of the adults hospitalized for COVID-19 with underlying conditions in the USA, 74.8% had chronic renal disease, but patients with chronic renal disease consisted of only 3% of total cases [26], [31]. A study from Washington found that of 24 patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU), five (21%) had chronic kidney disease [32]. In the Lombardy region of Italy, of 1591 ICU patients with COVID-19 from 72 hospitals, 36 (3%) had chronic kidney disease. Various studies from Wuhan, China, investigating the early stages of the pandemic found that 2â€“4% of COVID-19 patients had chronic renal failure [8], [25], [33]. However, in a lager study of 1099 cases from mainland China, only 0.7% of patients had chronic renal failure [5].
